items.title: ProcessFinishedWithError false positive for Java
items.body:
# The issue
Starting and stopping a Java application with TCPExecutor results in a mirakuru.exceptions.ProcessFinishedWithError (from https://github.com/ClearcodeHQ/mirakuru/blob/master/src/mirakuru/base.py#L352), as the JVM exits on exit code 143 for SIGTERM (http://journal.thobe.org/2013/02/jvms-and-kill-signals.html) instead of 9.

# How could it be fixed?
As an example the expected exit signal could be passed as an optional parameter
```
def stop(self: SimpleExecutorType, sig: int = None, exp_sig: int = 9) -> SimpleExecutorType:
```

# Current Workaround 
```
try:
   self.executor.stop()
except mirakuru.exceptions.ProcessFinishedWithError as e:
   default_jvm_sigkill_code = 143
   if e.exit_code != default_jvm_sigkill_code:
      raise e
```

items.title: Access exit code of process after `stop`
items.body: When calling [stop](https://mirakuru.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_modules/mirakuru/base.html#SimpleExecutor.stop), the process gets removed from the executor via `_clear_process()`. Without the process object, I don't know how to check if the process exited cleanly or not. What is the recommended approach to check for clean shutdown of processes managed by mirakuru?

items.title: module 'select' has no attribute 'poll' on Mac OS Python 3.8
items.body:
Using version 2.1.1 of mirakuru on Python 3.8.0 on Mac OS
```
$ pip freeze | grep mirakuru
mirakuru==2.1.1
```
It's easy to reproduce the error:
```
Python 3.8.0 (default, Dec 18 2019, 02:11:36) 
[Clang 11.0.0 (clang-1100.0.33.12)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import mirakuru
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/justyn/go/src/github.com/jharriman/carbyn-transit/transitparse/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/mirakuru/__init__.py", line 24, in <module>
    from mirakuru.output import OutputExecutor
  File "/Users/justyn/go/src/github.com/jharriman/carbyn-transit/transitparse/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/mirakuru/output.py", line 33, in <module>
    class OutputExecutor(SimpleExecutor):
  File "/Users/justyn/go/src/github.com/jharriman/carbyn-transit/transitparse/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/mirakuru/output.py", line 136, in OutputExecutor
    def _wait_for_output(self, *polls: Tuple[select.poll, IO[Any]]) -> bool:
AttributeError: module 'select' has no attribute 'poll'
```

It looks like there's been previous work before in #331, but that change did not properly fix the type annotations for `def _wait_for_output(self, *polls: Tuple[select.poll, IO[Any]])`. Likely the fix is as simple as adding quotes around `select.poll`.

items.title: Log exceptions on failed after_start_check and similar
items.body:
In #352 I had no output why the check fails and needed strace to find that the server returns 404 responses since it did not support  the default HEAD method used for the check.

There are much different reasons for failures due to e.g. the HTTP server not accepting requests or returning wrong status codes. A debug log message with each exception causing a mirakuru check to fail should help debug such misconfigurations more quickly.

items.title: HTTPExecutor.after_start_check leaks socket on error
items.body:
When I accidentally set a wrong method for the HTTPExecutor, I get many
```
Exception ignored in: <socket.socket fd=4, family=AddressFamily.AF_INET, type=SocketKind.SOCK_STREAM, proto=6, laddr=('127.0.0.1', 49218), raddr=('127.0.0.1', 18839)>
ResourceWarning: unclosed <socket.socket fd=4, family=AddressFamily.AF_INET, type=SocketKind.SOCK_STREAM, proto=6, laddr=('127.0.0.1', 49218), raddr=('127.0.0.1', 18839)>
```
(running on Python 3.7.)

We close the connection in case of a successful check, <https://github.com/ClearcodeHQ/mirakuru/blob/master/src/mirakuru/http.py#L109>, but not on error.

items.title: select.poll not available on default macos interpreter
items.body: Issue related: https://github.com/ClearcodeHQ/pytest-postgresql/issues/232

items.title: Latest release breaks up-stream packages
items.body:
We are all excited to drop python 2.0 support.

Alas - in this case - pytest-mongo (also from ClearcodeHQ) has a simple requirement.txt
that doesn't specify any mirakuru release - so this just broke pytest-mongo for python 2.7.
Not everyone is quite able/ready to drop 2.x support... I will also file an issue with pytest-mongo - since it you be a very simple fix for them..

items.title: Drop support for Python 3.5
items.body:
Until Buster is released (planned for July 2019, <https://lists.debian.org/debian-devel-announce/2019/06/msg00003.html>), it's still the newest Python in Debian, so it would be nice to keep for now. (PyPy has 3.6 beta since 7.1.0, I don't know which version Travis-CI has.)

Known useful new features:
* f-strings
* variable annotation syntax

items.title: Allow specifying working directory

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: No py2, close outstanding issues reported

items.body: It would be useful for the various Executors to accept a working directory argument (which would be passed down to `Popen`'s `cwd` argument).

items.title: Timeout not honoured for stop()
items.body:
The documentation for the `timeout` parameter to `SimpleExecutor.__init__()` says that it's applicable to both start and stop:
https://github.com/ClearcodeHQ/mirakuru/blob/dff7019e2b39afb23deda31a729d4412234fb6cf/src/mirakuru/base.py#L86-L87

Yet `SimpleExecutor.stop()` has a hardcoded 10s timeout: https://github.com/ClearcodeHQ/mirakuru/blob/dff7019e2b39afb23deda31a729d4412234fb6cf/src/mirakuru/base.py#L291

items.title: (Win23) AttributeError: module 'signal' has no attribute 'SIGKILL'
items.body:
Windows does not have the attribute 'SIGKILL' 

werkzeug had same problem and was fixed: 
https://github.com/pallets/werkzeug/commit/68e1ba06500914089723a3744a5ab93aa212b3a3

Can you apply a similar fix?

items.title: Make psutil dependency optional in order to support Cygwin platform
items.body:
Hi.

Currently, the installation of this dependency under Cygwin gives the following output:
```
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    platform cygwin is not supported
```

From what I found, this dependency seems optional:
- [dependency declaration in `setup.py`](https://github.com/ClearcodeHQ/mirakuru/blob/master/setup.py#L30)
- [usage in `src/mirakuru/base_env.py`](https://github.com/ClearcodeHQ/mirakuru/blob/master/src/mirakuru/base_env.py#L26)

Would it be possible to make this dependency optional please ?

items.title: OutputExecutor's banner argument does not applied to stderr
items.body:
According to SimpleExecutor's comment, it states captures stderr as well as stdout.

https://github.com/ClearcodeHQ/mirakuru/blob/2c4ea94d8b3e8dd4724c61486e44c5781604a73f/src/mirakuru/base.py#L151-L154

But its implementation does not handle stderr (only stdout)

https://github.com/ClearcodeHQ/mirakuru/blob/2c4ea94d8b3e8dd4724c61486e44c5781604a73f/src/mirakuru/base.py#L173-L181

https://github.com/ClearcodeHQ/mirakuru/blob/2c4ea94d8b3e8dd4724c61486e44c5781604a73f/src/mirakuru/base.py#L204-L208

https://github.com/ClearcodeHQ/mirakuru/blob/2c4ea94d8b3e8dd4724c61486e44c5781604a73f/src/mirakuru/base.py#L318-L321

It makes problem when use OutputExecutor, subclass of SimpleExecutor mentioned above. 
Consequently the`banner` option for constructor being ignored if a developer intended to capture it from stderr.

https://github.com/ClearcodeHQ/mirakuru/blob/2c4ea94d8b3e8dd4724c61486e44c5781604a73f/src/mirakuru/output.py#L92-L95

In my opinion, it is more consistent and useful if OutputExecutor can capture stderr too.

items.title: Non-HEAD HTTPExecutor Requests

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: No py2, close outstanding issues reported

items.body:
The HTTPExecutor currently uses HEAD requests to execute the after_start_check. Unfortunately that is not always the right method. I have the case where HEAD requests are refused by a server that I need to start, whereas GET requests work.

I think it would therefore be a good idea to make the HTTP method configurable.

items.title: Exception when executing dynamodb-local
items.body:
_Using: Python 3.5.2_

When using the TCPExecutor to execute the shell script /usr/local/bin/dynamodb-local (installed via homebrew), I get the following exception when exiting the main script.

I'm creating a "manage.py" script according to the flask docs located [here](http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/0.11/cli/#custom-scripts), and it looks like:

```
#!/usr/bin/env python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
"""Customized for running locally. DO NOT USE IN DEPLOYED ENVIRONMENTS"""
import os
import sys

import click
from flask.cli import FlaskGroup
from mirakuru import TCPExecutor

from myapp.settings import LOCAL_ENVIRONMENTS, get_config

here = os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))
sys.path.insert(0, here)


def create_myapp_app(info):
    from myapp.app import create_app
    return create_app()


@click.group(cls=FlaskGroup, create_app=create_myapp_app)
def cli():
    """This is a management script for the myapp application."""


if __name__ == '__main__':
    config = get_config()
    executor = None

    if config.NAME in LOCAL_ENVIRONMENTS:
        # Run local dynamo in the background
        executor = TCPExecutor(
            "dynamodb-local",
            host=config.FLYWHEEL_DATABASE_HOST,
            port=config.FLYWHEEL_DATABASE_PORT
        )
        try:
            executor.start()
        except FileNotFoundError as e:
            click.secho("dynamodb-local not found.", fg="red")
            click.secho("To install, you can either use homebrew, "
                        "or follow these instructions: https://goo.gl/OATMn4", fg="red")

    cli()

    if executor is not None:
        executor.stop()
        executor = None
```

And I get the following exception:

```

Exception ignored in: <bound method SimpleExecutor.__del__ of <mirakuru.tcp.TCPExecutor: "dynamodb-l..." 0x10cb522b0>>
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/plaster/.virtualenvs/myapp/lib/python3.5/site-packages/mirakuru/base.py", line 353, in __del__
  File "/Users/plaster/.virtualenvs/myapp/lib/python3.5/site-packages/mirakuru/base.py", line 307, in kill
  File "/Users/plaster/.virtualenvs/myapp/lib/python3.5/site-packages/mirakuru/base.py", line 227, in _kill_all_kids
  File "/Users/plaster/.virtualenvs/myapp/lib/python3.5/site-packages/mirakuru/base_env.py", line 52, in processes_with_env_psutil
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not callable
```

I'll see if I can look into this and possibly provide a pull request next week.  I kind of looks like it's being garbage cleaned before killing it's subprocesses.  I've seen this before when using **del**, but I can't remember what the solution was...

items.title: Unix socket executor

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: No py2, close outstanding issues reported

items.body:
It would get a socket path and check if the file exists and that a server accepts connections here.

Some services (e.g. MySQL) normally listen on both an Internet TCP socket and a Unix socket: we could subclass `TCPExecutor` into one keeping both host, port and socket path.

    def stop(self, sig=None):
        """
            Stop process running.

            Wait 10 seconds for the process to end, then just kill it.

            :param int sig: signal used to stop process run by executor.
                None for default.
            :returns: itself
            :rtype: SimpleExecutor

            .. note::

                When gathering coverage for the subprocess in tests,
                you have to allow subprocesses to end gracefully.

items.title: Killing (sig term) the process with executor doesn't call __del__() so subprocesses leaks
items.body:
Whenever I kill the process with SIG_TERM it doesn't actually call **del**() method of executors where we try to forcefully kill sub-processes. That's the expected python's behavior - it does not garbage collect objects when SIG_TERM is called.

To solve the issue we could catch this signal and kill sub-process forcefully. Each executor could add own signal handler in its `__init__()` and de-register in the `__del__()`

items.title: Incorporate good patterns from easyprocess into mirakuru
items.body:
http://easyprocess.readthedocs.org/en/latest/#usage
EasyProcess library has a nice style of calling subsequent methods:

```
.start().sleep(1).stop().stdout
```

To mimic this approach mirakuru would need to return `self` in most of Executor methods.

items.title: Define if 4XX and 5XX codes mean that HTTPExecutor actually started.
items.body:
I'd like to be able to treat `4XX` and `5XX` HTTP codes as valid responses of a running server.
My application has only one endpoint and I don't want to hit it during executor start as it influences the application's logic. Also I don't want to add a separate endpoint just for mirakuru startup test.

We could provide allowed status codes in the initialization:

```
HTTPExecutor('python server.py', '0.0.0.0', 8000, 'XXX').start()
```

or

```
HTTPExecutor('python server.py', '0.0.0.0', 8000, ('2XX', '4XX')).start()
```

items.title: Executor's context manager to return itself.
items.body:
I'd like to be able to fire executor inline:

```
from mirakuru import HTTPExecutor
with HttpExecutor('python my_server.py', 'http://127.0.0.1/status') as executor:
    yield executor
```

but unfortunately currently `Executor.__enter__()` doesn't return anything.

items.title: Passing the command as a list collides with shell=True
items.body:
What happens:

```
In [1]: from mirakuru import SimpleExecutor

In [2]: e = SimpleExecutor(['echo' , '"'], shell=True)

In [3]: e.start()

In [4]: /bin/sh: -c: line 0: unexpected EOF while looking for matching `"'
/bin/sh: -c: line 1: syntax error: unexpected end of file


In [4]: e.process.poll()
Out[4]: 1

In [5]: e.command
Out[5]: 'echo "'
```

What should probably happen:
The command should get shell-escaped and should be: `'echo \'"\''`

Shell-escaping is a cumbersome in Python stdlib because before 2.7 there was an undocumented function `quote` in `pipes`, in 2.7 it became documented and deprecated, in 3.0 it disappeared to reappear in 3.3 in `shlex` where it belongs.

We may use: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/shellescape or require commands to be passed as strings (unicodes) if `shell` is `True`.

By the way `subprocess.Popen` behaves weirdly when `shell=True` is used with a command as a list. What happens is the command-list gets glued to `['/bin/sh', '-c']`:

`args = ["/bin/sh", "-c"] + args`

And `/bin/sh` ignores everything but the first arg, like:

```
 sh -c 'echo aaa' asd asd a sdasd asa 
aaa
```

So If it makes no sense to pass lists with `shell=True`, let's maybe prohibit that.

items.title: Travis - this job ran on our legacy infrastructure
items.body:
For example: https://travis-ci.org/ClearcodeHQ/mirakuru/jobs/66110073

Look at the yellow notice.

items.title: Use subprocess32 (backport of Python 3.2/3.3 subprocess) rather than the stock subprocess
items.body:
As Python 2 documentation states:

> POSIX users (Linux, BSD, etc.) are strongly encouraged to install and use the much more recent subprocess32 module instead of the version included with python 2.7. It is a drop in replacement with better behavior in many situations.
> - https://docs.python.org/2.7/library/subprocess.html

We'll probably never support Windows (http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/windows) and I think the benefits of using the same module throughout various Python versions overweights the cost of moving Windows support from 'maybe some day' to 'na-ah'.

There is no easy way to compare `subprocess` functionality between different versions but IMO we should trust the official docs. 

https://pypi.python.org/pypi/subprocess32/ - `subprocess32`.
There is no established backport of 3.4's `subprocess`.

items.title: Have a finite default timeout
items.body:
```
class SimpleExecutor(object):
[...]
    def __init__(
            self, command, shell=False, timeout=None, sleep=0.1,
            sig_stop=signal.SIGTERM, sig_kill=signal.SIGKILL
    ):
[...]
        :param int timeout: time to wait for process to start or stop.
            if None, wait indefinitely.
[...]
```

This default makes short and obvious code hang if the after start check fails deterministically (e.g. since the started process is misconfigured, not working at all on a test machine). The solution is to pass the `timeout` argument to the executor and debug why the executor failed to start.

Unless for most uses of executors there is no reasonable maximum time needed to start the process, a finite default timeout should make such problems more obvious.

items.title: expose `StartCheckExecutor` directly as mirakuru.StartCheckExecutor
items.body: StartCheckExecutor might be more often used than plain Executor. It should be exposed in https://github.com/ClearcodeHQ/mirakuru/blob/master/mirakuru/__init__.py

items.title: tests failures on MacOS
items.body:
```
tests/executors/test_executor.py::test_process_output[echo -n "foobar"] FAILED
tests/executors/test_executor.py::test_process_output[command1] FAILED
tests/executors/test_executor.py::test_process_output_shell[echo -n "foobar"] FAILED
tests/executors/test_executor.py::test_process_output_shell[command1] FAILED
tests/executors/test_output_executor.py::test_executor_waits_for_process_output FAILED
tests/executors/test_output_executor.py::test_executor_dont_start FAILED
tests/executors/test_pid_executor.py::test_if_file_created FAILED
```

``` python
__________________________________________________________________________________________________ test_process_output[echo -n "foobar"] ___________________________________________________________________________________________________

command = 'echo -n "foobar"'

    @pytest.mark.parametrize('command', (echo_foobar, shlex.split(echo_foobar)))
    def test_process_output(command):
        """Start process, check output and shut it down."""
        executor = Executor(command)
        executor.start()

        assert executor.output().read() == 'foobar'
>       executor.stop()

command    = 'echo -n "foobar"'
executor   = <mirakuru.base.Executor: "echo -n "f..." 0x1064e7fd0>

tests/executors/test_executor.py:96: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 

self = <mirakuru.base.Executor: "echo -n "f..." 0x1064e7fd0>, sig = 15

    def stop(self, sig=None):
        """
            Stop process running.

            Wait 10 seconds for the process to end, then just kill it.

            :param int sig: signal used to stop process run by executor.
                None for default.

            .. note::

                When gathering coverage for the subprocess in tests,
                you have to allow subprocesses to end gracefully.
            """
        if self.process is None:
            return

        if sig is None:
            sig = self._sig_stop

>       os.killpg(self.process.pid, sig)
E       OSError: [Errno 1] Operation not permitted

self       = <mirakuru.base.Executor: "echo -n "f..." 0x1064e7fd0>
sig        = 15

mirakuru/base.py:171: OSError
```

items.title: Test for executors that run subprocesses
items.body: We have a lot of issues with running processes (databases, queue messages) that spawns own subprocesses. It happens that calling `.stop()` or `.kill()` doesn't actually stop or kill subprocesses. It might be tempting to use https://pypi.python.org/pypi/psutil/ to kill child subprocesses but we want to keep mirakuru independent of 3rd party libraries as much as it's possible. Perhaps it is worth to check how psutil kills kids.

items.title: Extend documentation with examples

milestone.title: v2.0
milestone.description: No py2, close outstanding issues reported

items.body:
README.rst lacks of usage examples. We should cover cases with different signals, context managers, all types of executors and corner cases.
The best way is to describe library usage as a story.

items.title: Ability to set signal with which try to end processes before terminating them
items.body: right now we're stopping them by default with SIGTERM. Though in order to end processes more gracefully, we might need to be able to set other signal to end processes.

items.title: Test executors with command argument passes as list or tuple too.
PidExecutor
items.body: To be implemented: executor waiting for a certain file to be created in a file system by a starting program. It should help to write integration tests for processes that notifies their start by creating .pid file. Solution should be documented and tested.

items.title: We should use ``super`` function if we want use new classes.
items.body: We should use `super` function if we want to use new classes. It is not required but it is concise.

items.title: start pre-check for executors
Properly terminate subprocesses started with shell True
items.body:
At the moment, if we start executor with shell true, and then stop it, it still keeps running in the background, as we're killing only shell that runs the process.

More on the issue here:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4789837/how-to-terminate-a-python-subprocess-launched-with-shell-true

items.title: command line executor runner
items.body:
Add command-line executor runner, that will be able to start and run processes defined in config file.

For example, having a mirakuru.yaml defined:

``` yaml
my_process:
    executor: Executor
    params: ....
database:
    executor: TCPExecutor
    command: postgresql
    host: localhost
    port: port
```

it should be possible to run just `mirakuru mirakuru.yaml` to start defined processes.

Maintaining of order of these processes will be required!

items.title: Use one command representation in executor
items.body:
Right now, after recent fix, we have two representantions throughout executor live. We should either
- keep one, preferably as one string, from start, getting correct form just before start (depending on shell flag).
- prepare only one or the other during executor creation dependant on shell flag

items.title: Wrong interpratation of commands with shell options enabled.
items.body:
There is a problem with proper interpretation of process command list with shell option enabled. It might be easily reproduced by calling: 

```
command = 'java -jar sth.jar'
OutputExecutor(command, 'sth', shell=True).start()
```

Output from this process looks like some arguments are missing to command, or like it can not interpret it. It still works with shell set to false.

items.title: Move conditional imports to compat.py module
items.body: Also, import rather based on sys.version_info rather than on ImportError

items.title: If subprocess stops printing anything, OutputCoordinatedExecutor hangs.
items.body:
This is due to readline() being stuck at waiting for any more output, while there's none. This will cause executor to hang on wait, even if there's a timeout set.

There's some idea on how to overcome this issue:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10756383/timeout-on-subprocess-readline-in-python

items.title: Expose process and other attributes on executor
items.body: For easier access to process, or elements like host and port

items.title: Write proper documentation
items.body:
Documentaion stub is already created.

We should have there both examples, along with explanatory documentation on usage of each executor, and API documentation.
- [x] API documentation
- [x] explanatory documentation on usage of each executor:
  - [x] Simple
  - [x] Output
  - [x] TCP
  - [x] HTTP

items.title: Unify executor's API
items.body:
Right now some timeout is being passed with constructor, stop method can only wait indefinitely for subprocess to stop, there's a kill method, that uses different kwarg to wait till subprocess is being killed. 

wait kwarg could be passed in constructor as well, or the wait should be default and use same timeout stop does.

This will allow executors to become their own context managers.

items.title: rewrite tests to py.test
items.body: we're already run tests through py.test, but would be great to rewrite them all as well to py.test-like tests for ease of use.

items.title: Add pylama with pep8, pyflakes, mccabe and pep257
items.body:
- [x] pep8 and pyflakes will set up a style guide rules for package
- [x] mccabe will guard against overly complex functions
- [ ] pep257 will at least force to think about docblocks
